header.title: Wicca A to Z: A Complete Guide to the Magickal World
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Wicca, Witchcraft, Goddess Worship

central_thesis: This book functions as a unique and comprehensive encyclopedia for modern Witches and anyone interested in the Earth's oldest religion (Wicca), covering its diverse traditions, magical arts, folklore, and jargon, with a strong emphasis on the worship and understanding of Pagan goddesses worldwide and their connection to the Divine Feminine.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART ONE: Magick, Myth, and Mysticism
structure_content.summary: This section alphabetically explores various facets of Wicca and the magickal arts. It delves into different Wiccan traditions, Sabbats (festivals) and rituals, specialized jargon, enchanting folklore, the use of amulets and talismans, and the numerous herbs associated with Witchcraft. This part provides a foundational understanding of the spiritual path and operative practices within Wicca.

structure_content.chapter_title: PART TWO: Goddesses From Around the World
structure_content.summary: As Wicca is a Goddess-oriented religion, this section is dedicated to an alphabetical listing of numerous Pagan goddesses from various cultures globally. Each entry details the unique deity, their attributes, and often highlights their relevance to or influence on contemporary Paganism and the Wiccan Craft, collectively representing the power, beauty, and magick of the Divine Feminine.

key_concepts.definition: An alternative name for modern Witchcraft; a Neo-Pagan Nature religion with spiritual roots in Shamanism, having one main tenet: the Wiccan Rede. The Goddess and Her consort the Horned God are the two main deities honored and worshipped in Wiccan rites.

The art, science, and practice of producing 'supernatural' effects, causing change to occur in conformity, and controlling events in Nature with will. The author uses the old spelling with a final 'k' to distinguish it from stage conjuring and illusion.

A simple and benevolent moral code of Wiccans stating: 'An it harm none, do what thou wilt.' It is interpreted as being free to act (magickally or mundanely) in accordance with one's heart, provided no harm is brought to others.

In Wicca, the belief that any energy (positive or negative, magickal or non-magickal) sent out will return to the sender threefold (or in some cases, sevenfold or greater) in the same lifetime, often immediately. This principle encourages ethical magical practice to avoid negative repercussions.

The supreme female aspect of the Divine; the consort of the Horned God (the male aspect of the Divine); and the main deity honored and invoked by many Wiccans. Her worship dates back to primitive times and she is known by myriad names across cultures.

In Wicca and Witchcraft, the consort of the Goddess and the symbol of male sexuality as well as the Divine Masculine. He presides over woodlands, wild animals, and the hunt. The Sun is His sacred symbol, and He is regarded as the lord of life, death, and the Underworld, essential for balancing nature's yin and yang.

One of the eight annual Wiccan festivals (four major/Grand and four minor/Lesser) celebrated by Witches, Wiccans, and Neo-Pagans at specific times of the year marking transitions in the seasons (e.g., Candlemas, Beltane, Lammas, Samhain, Spring Equinox, Summer Solstice, Autumn Equinox, Winter Solstice).

A regular meeting of a Witches' coven or circle, traditionally held during the full moon (approximately thirteen times a year), for exchanging ideas, discussing issues, performing special rites, working magick and healings, and offering thanks or requesting help from the Goddess and Horned God.

A black-handled ritual dagger with a double-edged blade, used by many Witches to draw their magick circles and to store and direct energy during magickal rituals. It is a sacred tool, never used for drawing blood, symbolizes the masculine aspect, and corresponds to the ancient element of Air.

In Wicca and Witchcraft, a ritual invocation of the Goddess spirit-force into the High Priestess of a coven by the High Priest (or by solitary practitioners). During this ritual, the High Priestess enters a trance-like altered state, draws the Goddess's power into herself, and functions as a channel or incarnate Goddess until the power is uncast.

practical_system.description: The book presents Wicca as a practical, nature-oriented, Goddess and Horned God worshipping religion, rooted in ancient traditions and emphasizing ethical conduct through the Wiccan Rede and the Threefold Law. Magick is an operative art used for positive purposes such as healing, protection, fertility, and spiritual growth, often aligned with lunar and seasonal cycles. It draws upon elemental energies, deity invocations, and symbolic tools for manifestation.
tools: Altar: A central consecrated surface for rituals, holding candles, incense, and ritual tools.
Athame: A black-handled ritual dagger for drawing circles and directing energy (Air element), never used for blood-drawing.
Chalice: A sacred cup or goblet for consecrated water or wine (Water element), used in rituals like 'Drawing Down the Moon'.
Censer: A metal vessel for burning incense (Air element), used to purify the circle and invoke elemental guardians.
Besom: A straw broom used as an altar decoration or tool to symbolize fertility and to ritually 'sweep clean' the magical circle of negative energy.
Wand/Scepter/Firestick: A stick (usually wood) used for tracing circles, drawing symbols, directing energy, and stirring cauldron brews (Air/Fire element).
Cauldron: A small or large, black cast-iron pot symbolizing the womb of the Goddess and combining the four elements, used for potions, incense, and herbs.
Crystal Ball: A sphere of crystal or glass used for scrying (divination through gazing at images within).
Tarot Cards: A deck of 78 cards used for divination, spiritual guidance, and dreamscaping, divided into Major and Minor Arcana.
Runestones: Stones or wooden sticks carved with runic symbols, used for divination and spellcasting.
Amulets/Talismans: Consecrated objects (stones, metal, jewelry) possessing magical power for protection, attracting luck, or specific intents.
Herbs: Plants with healing and magical properties, used in potions, spells, and remedies ('wortcunning').
Candles (colored): Used in candle magick, anointed and carved to represent specific attributes, influences, or emotions.
Image Dolls (Poppets): Herb-stuffed cloth dolls used in 'sympathetic magick' for healing, binding, or other spells, typically not for cursing in modern Wicca.
rituals: Sabbats: Eight annual festivals celebrating seasonal transitions (e.g., Beltane, Samhain, Spring Equinox, Winter Solstice) involving bonfires, dancing, feasts, and offerings.
Esbats: Monthly full moon gatherings for coven or solitary work, including spellcasting, healings, discussions, and deity communication, often involving 'Drawing Down the Moon' rituals.
Drawing Down the Moon/Sun: Ritual invocations to channel the Goddess's spirit into a High Priestess or the Horned God's spirit into a High Priest, transforming them into divine channels.
Consecration: The ritual act of making objects or spaces sacred, typically using water and salt to exorcise negative energies.
Banishing Rituals: Performed to remove negative or evil influences from a magical circle, often involving pentagrams and archangelic invocations.
Handfasting/Handparting: Wiccan wedding and dissolution ceremonies, respectively, symbolizing commitment 'for as long as love shall last' or its ending.
Wiccaning: A birth rite where a baby is named, anointed with salted water, and passed through incense smoke as a gesture of purification.

Circumambulation: Walking clockwise ('deosil') around a person, object, or site in rituals to bring good luck, cure diseases, bless the dead, or acquire magical powers, symbolizing life and positive energy.

relevant_quotes.text: Wicca A to Z is a unique encyclopedia for the modern Witch, as well as for anyone who is interested in the Earth's oldest religion.

As Wicca is essentially a Goddess-oriented religion and craft, the second section of this encyclopedia is devoted entirely to the many Pagan goddesses from around the world who collectively represent the power, the beauty, and the magick of the Divine Feminine.
The Wiccan Rede... 'An it harm none, do what thou wilt.'
The Great Rite... is in fact an extremely serious ritual, as it releases an enormous amount of power which is directed with magickal intent.

The custom of burning the previous year's corn dolly (or kirn baby) as part of the annual Lammas or Autumn Equinox Sabbat ritual bears a strong resemblance to, and perhaps even derives from, the ancient harvest rite dedicated to Zara-Mama.

Many modern Witches refer to their cats and dogs (and other pets) as familiars. They no doubt have a strong loving and spiritual bond with their animals, and may or may not cast spells and perform rituals with their familiars by their side.

critical_analysis.relevance: Gerina Dunwich's 'Wicca A to Z' is a foundational reference for understanding contemporary Wicca and Neo-Paganism. Its encyclopedic format makes complex concepts accessible, distinguishing Wicca from historical Witchcraft misconceptions (e.g., Satanism) and providing a glossary of terms critical for accurate discourse within the occult community. The detailed entries on deities, rituals, and magical practices offer practical insights for practitioners and scholars alike, particularly in its emphasis on nature-based spirituality and the Divine Feminine. The book also highlights the diverse traditions within Wicca, reflecting the eclectic and evolving nature of modern Paganism.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes modern Witches, Wiccans, and Neo-Pagans seeking a comprehensive reference guide to their practices and beliefs. It also caters to students of Western Esotericism, occultism, comparative religion, and mythology, as well as general readers interested in a factual and detailed overview of Witchcraft and Pagan traditions. The A-Z format is particularly beneficial for those seeking quick, precise definitions and contextual information.
